title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION: The Consumer Credit Protection Act is amended to include provisions for protecting financial information privacy. TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION: The Consumer Credit Protection Act is amended to include provisions for protecting financial information privacy. This title, known as the Financial Information Privacy Act, includes definitions such as 'customer' and 'customer information of a financial institution'. It also covers privacy protection for customer information, enforcement measures, civil liability, criminal penalties, and guidance for agencies. The term 'financial institution' is defined as any institution providing financial services to customers with credit, deposit, trust, or other financial accounts. This includes depository institutions, loan companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may define 'financial institution' further through regulations. It is prohibited to obtain customer information through false pretenses, such as making fraudulent statements to deceive financial institution employees or customers. It is prohibited to deceive customers or employees of a financial institution by making fraudulent statements or providing forged documents to obtain customer information. Additionally, requesting someone to obtain customer information under false pretenses is also a violation. The section prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through deceptive means. It does not apply to law enforcement agencies or certain cases involving financial institutions testing security procedures, investigating misconduct, or recovering customer information. The section prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through deceptive means. Compliance with this title is enforced by the Federal Trade Commission, with exceptions for certain cases where other agencies may enforce it. Enforced under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency oversees national banks, Federal branches, and agencies of foreign banks. The Board regulates member banks of the Federal Reserve System, foreign bank branches, commercial lending companies, and organizations under the Federal Reserve Act. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation oversees banks insured by them. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act enforces regulations on national banks, Federal branches, and foreign bank agencies. The Board of Directors of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation oversees insured State branches of foreign banks and savings associations. Violations of this act are treated as violations of other laws by relevant agencies. State authorities can take legal action against violations of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act, including seeking injunctions, recovering damages up to $1,000 per violation, and being awarded costs and attorney fees for successful actions. State authorities must provide prior written notice to the Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies before taking legal action under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The FTC and agencies have the right to intervene in the action and be heard on all matters. State authorities must provide notice to the FTC before taking legal action under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The FTC and agencies have the right to intervene in the action and be heard on all matters, including the ability to remove the action to the appropriate US district court and file petitions for appeal. Investigatory powers are preserved for state officials to conduct investigations and compel witnesses or evidence. If the FTC or relevant agencies have initiated a civil action, no State can bring a separate action under this section while the federal action is pending. "Sec. 1005. Civil liability states that any person failing to comply with this title regarding financial institutions or customer information is liable for actual damages sustained by the institution or customer, plus any amount received due to the failure. Additional damages may also be imposed." Sec. 1006 imposes criminal penalties for violating section 1003, including fines and imprisonment up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving violations of other laws or illegal activities exceeding $100,000 in a 12-month period. Sec. 1007 clarifies that this title does not supersede state laws. Sec. 1008 requires Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to assist depository institutions in deterring and detecting prohibited activities. The Comptroller General must report to Congress within 18 months of the enactment of this Act, in consultation with relevant agencies. The report to Congress will assess the effectiveness of remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and make recommendations for additional legislative or regulatory actions to protect financial privacy.
